docs.lead_paragraph: Given the opportunity, many men will gladly spend time gazing at beautiful women's faces. Though the news may not come as much of a shock, the researchers who report the finding in a new study say it may still lend some insight into how the brain works.

headline.main: Beauty, It Turns Out, Lights the Brain

docs.abstract: Study finds that men's response to facial beauty is located in same area of brain that is activated by food, recreational drugs and money and that men will look longer at a face the more beautiful they find it; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Given the opportunity, many men will gladly spend time gazing at beautiful women's faces.    Though the news may not come as much of a shock, the researchers who report the finding in a new study say it may still lend some insight into how the brain...

docs.lead_paragraph: The simple act of placing a baby with Down syndrome on a treadmill to practice walking early in life can yield a wide range of developmental benefits, both physical and emotional, a new study reports. Researchers from the University of Michigan, writing in the current issue of Pediatrics, report that the infants began walking an average of three and a half months sooner if they were placed on special treadmills, at first with support under their arms, for eight minutes a day, five days a week.

headline.main: Early Walking for Babies With Down's

docs.abstract: Placing baby with Down syndrome on treadmill to practice walking early in life is found to yield wide range of developmental benefits, both physical and emotional (M)
docs.snippet: The simple act of placing a baby with Down syndrome on a treadmill to practice walking early in life can yield a wide range of developmental benefits, both physical and emotional, a new study reports.    Researchers from the University of Michigan,...

docs.lead_paragraph: It has long been known that many patients who have angioplasty to clear blockages from blood vessels supplying the heart experience a return of the clogging. Angioplasty involves briefly inflating a balloon inside an artery to compress the blockages. But a new study reports that half the people suffering recurrences may have no symptoms, and so no hint that they may be at increased risk of heart attacks.
docs.abstract: Study finds that arteries of heart patients who undergo angioplasty may clog up again without causing symptoms; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: It has long been known that many patients who have angioplasty to clear blockages from blood vessels supplying the heart experience a return of the clogging. Angioplasty involves briefly inflating a balloon inside an artery to compress the blockages....

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly people who have osteoarthritis, the most common form of arthritis, may benefit from beginning a martial arts program, a new study suggests. But no one is proposing that arthritis patients start kicking wooden boards apart. Instead, the researchers suggest tai chi, the 1,200-year-old practice that originated in China and consists of slow, fluid, almost meditative movements.
docs.abstract: Elderly people with osteoarthritis are found to benefit from tai chi program (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bones, once taken for granted, have become a major health issue now that so many Americans are living well into their 70's, 80's and beyond. For at least half of women and one in eight men, bones are not bearing up as well as they should to sustain an active, independent old age free of debilitating fractures. As a result, osteoporosis -- bones seriously weakened by mineral loss -- has become a household word, as familiar to most people as cholesterol. And the pharmaceutical industry, supplement makers and now food producers have responded with products intended to keep Americans from breaking apart before their time on earth is up.

headline.main: Growing Old, With the Bones in One Piece

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on osteoporosis, how to protect oneself against it and drugs that foster healthy bone growth; says habits of young Americans today portend future epidemic of osteoporosis that far exceeds today's problems; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the day after she completed a marathon, Lindsey Nohr learned that a lesion on her tongue was cancerous. She could cope with cancer, she thought, but at age 22, she found one potential consequence of chemotherapy unbearable: infertility. Drugs that kill cancer cells can also destroy a woman's eggs. ''When my doctor told me there was a 25 to 30 percent chance I'd become infertile, I was devastated,'' she said. ''I even considered not doing chemotherapy at all.''

headline.main: Studies Aim to Preserve Fertility of Women in Chemotherapy

docs.abstract: More and more women with cancer are demanding ways to remain fertile after chemotherpy, and thanks to advances in oncology and reproductivity endocrinology, there has been surge of scientific activity on protecting ovaries from ravages of cancer drugs; two main avenues of study are freezing eggs and identifying drugs that may protect ovaries; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bioterrorists want a horrible disease that is easy to spread and that has a high fatality rate. So, thought terrorists during the Civil War, what better disease than yellow fever? It kills within days, causing a hemorrhagic fever that makes victims bleed from the mouth and nose and vomit a black substance that resembles coffee grounds but consists largely of dried blood. There was no effective treatment for yellow fever and no way to prevent it, and it could spread rapidly through a city, causing panic and social disruption.

headline.main: New York Was Bioterrorism Target, in 1864

docs.abstract: Today's concerns about bioterrorism prompt recall of attempt by Southern sympathizers to seed yellow fever epidemic in New York and other Northern cities during Civil War (M)
docs.snippet: Bioterrorists want a horrible disease that is easy to spread and that has a high fatality rate. So, thought terrorists during the Civil War, what better disease than yellow fever? It kills within days, causing a hemorrhagic fever that makes victims...

docs.lead_paragraph: When they fell in love, she was barely into her teens, and he wasn't much older. Some saw a star-crossed couple who found understanding, joy and maturity in each other's arms. Others saw impulsive kids whose reckless passion cut them off from family, friends and more appropriate interests, provoked mood swings, delinquent behavior and experimentation with drugs, and ended in tragedy. Romeo and Juliet's story is centuries old, but these two very different views of adolescent romance live on, often simultaneously, in the minds of bemused parents.

headline.main: Young Love: The Good, the Bad and the Educational

docs.abstract: Researchers studying teenage dating and romance find potentially positive effects as well as negative one for adolescence and adult relationships and well-being; says teenagers need adult supervision and rules, like curfews, and parents should be alert to signs that relationship is becoming too consuming, reduces other social contacts or incites jealousy and feelings of ownership and coercion; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shapely sperm are the best indicator of a man's fertility, according to a study that rewrites the standards for analyzing semen samples. Current standards misjudge many men's fertility, said the study, published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: When Rating Male Fertility, Appearance Counts

docs.abstract: Researchers find that best indicator of male fertility is shapeliness of sperm; says well-shaped sperm has, among other things, oval head and whippy tail; photo (M)
